text: One of our SMB customers who's into automation software designing,
they have been given around eight million to upgrade their data center and to refresh the hardware.
As for the customer, that's a big CapEx.
They asked for our help to assess their application and how we can help them move into the cloud.

So the biggest challenge this customer had is lack of skills
within team related to cloud.
The other challenge they have is related to legacy application where they do not even have access to the source code.
In phase one, we started accessing the customer's application.

Which was a very small application,
but from business point of view, it has a high KPI value.
In phase two, because of the tight deadline, we have opted for lift and shift approach where we have migrated the virtual machines to EC2.
So after the migration, this customer is doing a lot of innovation within AWS and continuously improving their application.
So, the customer began to realize the value of moving into AWS during their second phase.
They started to save around 70% in operational costs.
That's just not it, because this customer is providing their software to other businesses.
The SLAs, the downtime has reduced and they're starting to meet their SLAs which was around 95%.
In phase three, they have started with cost optimization exploring microservice architecture and serverless architecture.
So instead of running their application on EC2, they convert them into containers so they can port them in ECS or EKS.

The customer realized that they're saving around
50 to 60% of cost by moving into AWS.
And that's just not it. On operations, they have saved around 70%.
So for this particular use case, it took the customer three months for phase one. And phase two was done within six months.
This use case is important for SMB customers, because as per Gartner's Research, by 2025, 80% of data center will be closed.
If there's no data center, where would I run my workload? AWS Cloud is an answer for this problem.
